<label>17</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 675, 91]]<|/det|>
Which statement describes a sensitive liquid-in-glass thermometer?

<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 100, 908, 119]]<|/det|>
a thermometer which can be used to measure very high and very low values of temperature

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 127, 133, 144]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 125, 920, 160]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 168, 133, 186]]<|/det|>

<label>D</label>

<label>18</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 253, 922, 288]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 300, 581, 319]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 358, 133, 377]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[288, 358, 321, 377]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[485, 358, 534, 377]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 358, 636, 377]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 358, 702, 377]]<|/det|>
28℃

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 405, 106, 424]]<|/det|>
<label>19</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 405, 784, 424]]<|/det|>
A student sets up four cans. Each can contains the same mass of water at \(90^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 435, 564, 453]]<|/det|>
The cans are identical except for the outside surfaces.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 465, 428, 483]]<|/det|>
Which can will cool down the fastest?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 494, 133, 512]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 494, 304, 512]]<|/det|>
dull, black surface

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 521, 133, 539]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 521, 304, 539]]<|/det|>
dull, white surface

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 548, 131, 566]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 548, 319, 566]]<|/det|>
shiny, black surface

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 574, 131, 592]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 574, 319, 592]]<|/det|>
shiny, white surface

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 617, 106, 635]]<|/det|>
<label>20</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 617, 604, 635]]<|/det|>
Thermal energy is transferred by conduction in a metal bar.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 647, 384, 664]]<|/det|>
Which statement is not correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 675, 133, 692]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 675, 457, 692]]<|/det|>
Fast vibrating ions leave the surface.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 701, 131, 720]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 701, 650, 720]]<|/det|>
Free moving electrons carry thermal energy through the bar.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 728, 131, 746]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 728, 670, 746]]<|/det|>
Ions vibrate and strike neighbouring ions to make them vibrate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 755, 133, 772]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 755, 479, 772]]<|/det|>
Ions vibrate but do not change position.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 104, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 705, 89]]<|/det|> A water wave passes into a region where the wave travels more slowly. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 102, 920, 135]]<|/det|> As it passes into the slow region, what happens to the frequency and what happens to the wavelength of the wave? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 147, 544, 273]]<|/det|>
frequencywavelength
Adecreasesremains the same
Bincreasesremains the same
Cremains the samedecreases
Dremains the sameincreases
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 304, 106, 322]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 303, 920, 336]]<|/det|> Light travelling at a speed of \(3.0 \times 10^{8} \text{m/s}\) strikes the surface of a glass block and undergoes refraction as it enters the block. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 348, 712, 367]]<|/det|> The diagram shows a ray of this light before and after it enters the block. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 375, 683, 543]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 555, 437, 572]]<|/det|> What is the speed of light in the glass? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 584, 134, 602]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 584, 268, 602]]<|/det|> \(1.8 \times 10^{8} \text{m/s}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 612, 134, 630]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 612, 268, 630]]<|/det|> \(2.0 \times 10^{8} \text{m/s}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 640, 134, 658]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 640, 268, 658]]<|/det|> \(4.5 \times 10^{8} \text{m/s}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 667, 134, 685]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 667, 268, 685]]<|/det|> \(5.0 \times 10^{8} \text{m/s}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 711, 106, 728]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 711, 789, 728]]<|/det|> Which statement about the image of an object formed in a plane mirror is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 740, 134, 757]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 740, 381, 757]]<|/det|> It is smaller than the object. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 766, 134, 784]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 766, 418, 784]]<|/det|> It is the same size as the object. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 794, 134, 811]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 794, 366, 811]]<|/det|> It is larger than the object. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 820, 134, 836]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 820, 260, 836]]<|/det|> It is inverted.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>24</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 547, 90]]<|/det|>
An object is placed in front of a thin converging lens.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 672, 120]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the paths of two rays from the top of the object.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[297, 128, 695, 275]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 286, 675, 306]]<|/det|>
An image of the object is formed on a screen to the right of the lens.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 317, 504, 336]]<|/det|>
How does this image compare with the object?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 345, 134, 364]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 345, 348, 364]]<|/det|>
It is larger and inverted.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 371, 133, 390]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 371, 423, 390]]<|/det|>
It is larger and the same way up.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 397, 133, 416]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 397, 361, 416]]<|/det|>
It is smaller and inverted.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 422, 133, 441]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 422, 435, 441]]<|/det|>
It is smaller and the same way up.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 467, 106, 486]]<|/det|>
<label>25</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 467, 692, 486]]<|/det|>
Here are three statements about the speed of electromagnetic waves.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 497, 747, 516]]<|/det|>
1 The speed of an electromagnetic wave in a vacuum is \(340 \text{m / s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 524, 791, 544]]<|/det|>
2 The speed of an electromagnetic wave in a vacuum is \(3.0 \times 10^{8} \text{m / s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 551, 920, 586]]<|/det|>
3 The speed of an electromagnetic wave in a vacuum is approximately the same as in air.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 596, 371, 613]]<|/det|>
Which statements are correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 624, 134, 642]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 624, 180, 642]]<|/det|>
1 and 3

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 624, 298, 642]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[306, 624, 373, 642]]<|/det|>
1 only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 624, 468, 642]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 624, 552, 642]]<|/det|>
2 and 3

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 624, 636, 642]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[640, 624, 707, 642]]<|/det|>
2 only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 415, 107, 434]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 415, 554, 434]]<|/det|> Which method does **not** demagnetise a bar magnet? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 444, 134, 463]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 444, 700, 463]]<|/det|> Heat the bar magnet and place it in the east-west direction to cool. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 470, 131, 489]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 470, 670, 489]]<|/det|> Place the bar magnet in the east-west direction and hammer it. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 497, 131, 515]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 497, 819, 515]]<|/det|> Place the bar magnet in a coil connected to an a.c. supply and slowly withdraw it. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 523, 133, 542]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 523, 809, 542]]<|/det|> Place the bar magnet in a coil connected to a d.c. supply and slowly withdraw it.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 104, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 858, 89]]<|/det|> Three piles of small nails, P, Q and R, are placed on a bench below three electromagnets. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 677, 119]]<|/det|> One set of nails is made of copper, one of soft iron and one of steel. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 133, 720, 149]]<|/det|> Diagram 1 shows the situation when the electromagnets are switched on. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 163, 761, 179]]<|/det|> Diagram 2 shows the situation when the electromagnets are then switched off. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[104, 191, 895, 368]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[373, 412, 562, 428]]<|/det|> diagram 2 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[373, 428, 562, 445]]<|/det|> the switches are open <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[104, 458, 895, 585]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 604, 734, 621]]<|/det|> Which row correctly identifies the materials from which the nails are made? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 634, 489, 763]]<|/det|>
coppersoft ironsteel
APQR
BPRQ
CQPR
DQRP

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>29</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 472, 89]]<|/det|>
A magnet is suspended by a cotton thread.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 728, 120]]<|/det|>
The magnet is displaced then allowed to swing freely until it comes to rest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 133, 725, 150]]<|/det|>
Why does the magnet always come to rest pointing in the same direction?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 161, 134, 178]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 160, 920, 193]]<|/det|>
because of the interaction between the electric field of the magnet and the electric field of the Earth

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 202, 134, 220]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 202, 920, 234]]<|/det|>
because of the interaction between the electric field of the magnet and the magnetic field of the Earth

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 243, 133, 260]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 243, 920, 275]]<|/det|>
because of the interaction between the magnetic field of the magnet and the gravitational field of the Earth

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 285, 133, 301]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 285, 920, 316]]<|/det|>
because of the interaction between the magnetic field of the magnet and the magnetic field of the Earth

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 343, 106, 361]]<|/det|>
<label>30</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 343, 447, 359]]<|/det|>
A student rubs a plastic rod with a cloth.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 373, 421, 390]]<|/det|>
The rod becomes positively charged.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 403, 379, 420]]<|/det|>
What has happened to the rod?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 432, 133, 450]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 432, 346, 448]]<|/det|>
It has gained electrons.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 459, 133, 476]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 459, 336, 476]]<|/det|>
It has gained protons.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 485, 133, 503]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 485, 320, 501]]<|/det|>
It has lost electrons.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 511, 133, 528]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 511, 306, 527]]<|/det|>
It has lost protons.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 555, 106, 572]]<|/det|>
<label>31</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 555, 500, 572]]<|/det|>
An isolated metal sphere is positively charged.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 584, 690, 601]]<|/det|>
It is then brought near to another isolated metal sphere that is neutral.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 610, 808, 718]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 732, 920, 764]]<|/det|>
What happens to the charges on the neutral sphere as the positively charged sphere is brought close to it?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 776, 134, 794]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 776, 856, 793]]<|/det|>
Some positive charges move to the left and some negative charges move to the right.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 802, 133, 819]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 802, 856, 819]]<|/det|>
Some positive charges move to the right and some negative charges move to the left.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 829, 133, 846]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 829, 811, 846]]<|/det|>
Some positive charges move to the right, but the negative charges do not move.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 855, 133, 873]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 855, 803, 871]]<|/det|>
The positive charges do not move, but some negative charges move to the left.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 107, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 529, 89]]<|/det|> Which circuit has a zero reading on the ammeter? <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[225, 98, 779, 390]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 414, 106, 432]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 414, 636, 432]]<|/det|> Two \(10\Omega\) resistors are connected in series and then in parallel. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 444, 507, 462]]<|/det|> What is the combined resistance in each case? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 473, 432, 621]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 920, 120]]<|/det|> A solenoid is connected to a very sensitive ammeter. A rod is inserted into one end of the solenoid. The ammeter shows that there is a small electric current in the solenoid while the rod is moving. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 128, 751, 234]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 248, 354, 266]]<|/det|> Which rod is being inserted? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 277, 134, 295]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 277, 322, 295]]<|/det|> a heated copper rod <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 304, 134, 321]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 303, 344, 320]]<|/det|> a magnetised steel rod <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 330, 134, 348]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 330, 354, 348]]<|/det|> an uncharged nylon rod <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 356, 134, 374]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 356, 364, 373]]<|/det|> a radioactive uranium rod <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 400, 106, 418]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 400, 401, 418]]<|/det|> The diagram shows a transformer. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 426, 690, 603]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 615, 344, 633]]<|/det|> What is the output voltage? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 644, 134, 661]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 644, 207, 661]]<|/det|> 0.35V <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[285, 644, 313, 661]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[320, 644, 364, 661]]<|/det|> 2.9V <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 644, 476, 661]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 644, 551, 661]]<|/det|> 4600V <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[621, 644, 641, 661]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[650, 644, 737, 661]]<|/det|> 105 000 V <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 689, 106, 707]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 689, 900, 707]]<|/det|> Which row correctly states how nuclei behave during nuclear fission and during nuclear fusion? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 718, 598, 848]]<|/det|>
fissionfusion
Anuclei join togethernuclei join together
Bnuclei join togethernuclei split apart

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 287, 106, 305]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 287, 920, 320]]<|/det|> Some radioactive nuclei decay to give new nuclei which are also radioactive. Part of a series of decays is shown. <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 331, 801, 361]]<|/det|> \[^{238}_{92}\mathrm {U}\rightarrow ^{234}_{90}\mathrm {Th}\rightarrow ^{234}_{91}\mathrm {Pa}\rightarrow ^{234}_{92}\mathrm {U}\rightarrow ^{230}_{90}\mathrm {Th}\rightarrow ^{226}_{88}\mathrm {Ra}\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 376, 571, 394]]<|/det|> How many decays involve the emission of a \(\beta\) -particle? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 405, 134, 422]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[143, 405, 163, 422]]<|/det|> 1 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 405, 298, 422]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 405, 331, 422]]<|/det|> 2 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 405, 475, 422]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[478, 405, 497, 422]]<|/det|> 3 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 405, 635, 422]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[638, 405, 668, 422]]<|/det|> 5 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 451, 106, 470]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 450, 725, 469]]<|/det|> The graph shows the activity of a radioactive source over a period of time. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[304, 478, 688, 660]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 676, 401, 694]]<|/det|> What is the half-life of the source? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 705, 133, 723]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 705, 243, 723]]<|/det|> 1.0 minute <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 705, 300, 723]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 705, 420, 723]]<|/det|> 2.0 minutes <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 705, 470, 723]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 705, 588, 723]]<|/det|> 2.5 minutes <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 705, 636, 723]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 705, 703, 723]]<|/det|> 4.0 minutes <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 836, 920, 871]]<|/det|> Permission to reproduce items where third-party owned material protected by copyright is included has been sought and cleared where possible.
